Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Hacktion: Cybersecurity Education Through Pervasive Mixed-Reality Experience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Entrepreneurial Game Studio at Drexel University seeks to design and prototype a mixed reality activity, Hacktion, to increase people's knowledge and awareness of cybersecurity best practices. This research and development project integrates the real world, in particular urban landscapes, with a digital world via GPS-enabled mobile devices, similar to popular commercial apps like Pokemon Go. In this prototype project, the city becomes the activity space. Participants must move within close proximity of a building - which, in the prototype, represents a server - and probe it using simulated cybersecurity methods. The app asks learners to engage physically and mentally with the learning tasks they face, increasing their understanding of cybersecurity and computer science. Hacktion is an educational experience that takes learning into an informal setting of the streets.

Pervasive mixed-reality (PMR) games are a revolutionary and highly experimental approach to interactive entertainment. These games have been made possible only through technological advances in GPS accuracy, fast, reliable mobile networks, and powerful mobile operating systems that have occurred over the last five years. This research project will utilize the convergence of these relatively new mass market technologies to create an experimental PMR educational game about cybersecurity that is fun, engaging, and encourages physical activity. Instead of relying on the conventional drill-and-practice approach commonly found in educational games, this project requires players to learn about cybersecurity by analyzing company servers that are represented by local landmarks in the world around them. This combination of pervasive mixed-reality games, mobile technologies, and physical activity represents the vanguard of experimental work in the fields of both educational games and cybersecurity education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to identify important cybersecurity principles, then develop a prototype mobile game, Hacktion, that integrates fun Pervasive Mixed Reality (PMR) gameplay with game-based learning about these principles. After developing a functional Beta build of the Hacktion application, we discovered that an accessible mobile game can engage users across multiple play sessions and has the potential to communicate core cybersecurity principles without intimidating users with overly complex explanations or impenetrable technical jargon.

We also learned that a constellation of recent technological advancements (high speed wireless networks, increased sophistication of mobile devices, improvements in GPS and the proliferation of free open source game tools) has made the development of PMR games in the vein of Pokmemon GO!  possible for even small academic teams with limited budgets. Our research during this period shows that while games can be effective educational tools, few have attempted to use PMR games in an educational context. Because PMR games are uniquely embedded in the world around us, they have the potential to engage learners in multiple non-classroom contexts. 

Our most significant findings in the realm of game-based education were discovered between the Alpha and Beta phases of development. It became clear during the Alpha test that our game experience included too many features, and therefore taxed the attention of our users to such a degree that the game failed to communicate the core cybersecurity principles our designers meant to communicate. The team decided that in order to create space for our educational content the core gameplay needed to be dramatically simplified. In addition, the team decided that in order to ensure educational objectives were achieved the game had to communicate cybersecurity principles both implicitly through game mechanics as well as explicitly through in-­game text. After this dramatic redesign, we tested the clarified product in the Beta phase, and found that the cybersecurity principles were better represented because we could engage players for a longer period of time. 

As part of the EGS mission to increase STEM opportunities for underrepresented populations through game design, the Hacktion project supported a diverse team of undergraduate researchers and developers. Hacktion’s primary undergraduate researcher, for example, was one of only female Game Design students at Drexel to move on to a PhD in her field, and was recently awarded the Presidential Fellowship at Georgia Tech. The lead developer, a game designer of color, moved on to start an independent game studio, run a successful crowd funding campaign, and win multiple awards for his debut title.

In future phases of the project we will test the efficacy of Hacktion as a learning tool in larger and more diverse populations, compare our learning methods against more traditional classroom forms, and test the potential for PMR games as a learning tool in informal environments.
